Tool that can be used to perform exercises lengthening and strengthening the torso, shoulders, back and legs while correcting or restoring the spine’s natural curvature.
Machine used for pilates.
A Pilates accessory and a catalyst, driving enhanced performance, flexibility, and alignment in one's Pilates routine.
An elastic band that adds resistance to your Pilates exercises.
A lacrosse stick shaft is the longer part of the stick.
The mesh fabric used to score goals by lacrosse players.
A long-handled stick used for playing the position of lacrosse goalie, having a curved L-shaped or triangular frame at one end with a piece of netting in the angle.
The protective equipment worn on the shins of lacrosse players
Stick is used to handle the ball and strike or check the opposing player in the sport of lacrosse.
The protective equipment worn on the hands of lacrosse players
A group of tools used to train on the lacrosse sport.
The preformed material used to string the head of a lacrosse stick.
The fixture used to score goals by lacrosse players
A kit containing components to string the head of a lacrosse stick.
A solid rubber ball used with a stick to play the sport of lacrosse.
The protective equipment worn on the shoulders of lacrosse players.
The top of the shaft of a lacrosse stick used for catching, picking up and cradling the balls.
The material used in conjunction with mesh to string the head of a lacrosse stick.
The pants worn by lacrosse players
The protective equipment worn on the upper body of lacrosse players.
The protective equipment worn on the head of lacrosse players
A rectangular shaped equipment for lacrosse skill practice.
A lacrosse set is full set of lacrosse equipment packaged together for sport play.
Eyewear or eyewear shaped open frames worn by lacrosse players.
Protective equipment worn on the hands of lacrosse goalies.
The protective equipment worn on the elbows of lacrosse players.
Handles for oars and paddles.
A small, narrow watercraft which is typically propelled by means of a double-bladed paddle.
A classifier for items in “Kayaking Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Accessory items related to canoes.
A flexible waterproof cover for a kayak with holes for the passengers' waists.
Paddles and oars used in canoes, kayaks, and paddleboards.
A cart used for transporting kayaks.
A pole with a flat blade, pivoting in an oar lock, used to row or steer a boat through the water.
A narrow, keelless boat with pointed ends, propelled by a paddle or paddles.
Accessory items related to paddles and oars.
A large board that a rider stand upon while using a paddle to propel themselves through the water.
A strut placed crosswise (left/right) in a ship or boat, to brace it crosswise. In rowboats it can also serve as a seat for a rower.
The part of the oar or paddle that enters the water.
Protective cover for a paddle or oar.

productTypeGroup.description: Hockey Chest Protectors a protective pad worn over the chest by a catcher shield the body.

productType.description: A piece of equipment that is used off-ice yet simulates a puck on ice.
A close-fitting glove augmented on the back of the hand, wrist and part of the forearm by a rectangular "block" of padding and fabric worn by ice and roller hockey goaltenders.
A long handled stick with a curved flat section at the bottom used by hockey goailes.
A small black flat roundel of hardened rubber used as a playing piece in ice hockey to score points by moving the puck into the opponent's goal net.
A physical structure made from a frame and a net used to denote scoring in hockey.
The long length of a hockey stick between the butt end and the blade.
Protective equipment worn on the legs of hockey goalies
Face and head protective gear worn by hockey goalies
A single upc, sku, or product containing multiple different types of hockey products
A glove worn on the free hand of a goalie with  padding to protect the lower forearm, wrist, palm, fingers and thumb, and a deeper pocket to catch a hockey puck
Protective equipment designed to protect the chest, shoulders, arms, and collarbone area from the impact of pucks and is worn under the hockey jersey.
Protective equipment worn on the shins of hockey players.
A surface that simulates ice for off-ice practice.
Glove used by hockey goalie used to catch the puck in gameplay.
Protective equipment worn on the shoulders by hockey players.
A classifier for items in “Hockey Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Protective equipment worn on the hips of hockey players.
Protective equipment worn on the elbows of hockey players.
Stick used to shoot, pass, and carry the puck across the ice in hockey.
A ball used in floor hockey.
Protective equipment worn on the heads of hockey players.
A piece of plastic or plastic like material that is installed on the facemask of a hockey helmet.
Protective equipment worn on the hands of hockey players.
Mock ups and targets of a hockey goal used by players to practice shots.

Garments or large belts that are worn tightly around the midsection. People wear them either under their clothes during the day to give the appearance of a slimmer waist or hourglass figure or to help them sweat more during workouts in the hopes of boosting fat loss efforts.
Apparel to be worn during a triathlon.
Fitness Charts & Planners that help track progress for fitness journeys.
Durable floor pad designed for improving stability and ankle/leg strength exercises.
A device with a vibrating platform that you can stand (or sit) on.
A firm, very large, usually inflatable ball used in various exercises, chiefly to strengthen the back, pelvis, and abdominal muscles.
Electrical-stimulation abdominal belts cause muscles to contract, giving your abdominal muscles a workout without doing a single sit-up, according to companies that sell the devices.
A personal monitoring device that allows one to measure/display heart rate in real time or record the heart rate for later study.
Flooring that is typically placed under workout equipment to help protect the floor from impact.
Fabric straps designed to provide stability, grip, etc. for lifting weights.
Vest with weights sewn into it.

Collars are used to prevent plates from moving outward unevenly so that the lifter does not experience uneven force. The barbell is the longer version of the dumbbell that is used for free weight training and competitive sports, such as powerlifting, Olympic weight lifting, and CrossFit.
Gloves worn by weightlifters.
Boards that you stand on to help with balance and core strength.
A piece of equipment that can be used to perform a wide number of agility drills. It is in a shape of a ladder and can be laid flat on the ground.
A piece of equipment that can be attached for a machine to target various muscle groups.

An activity tracker, also known as a fitness tracker, is a device or application for monitoring and tracking fitness-related metrics such as distance walked or run, calorie consumption, and in some cases heartbeat. It is a type of wearable computer.
Gear bags built especially for triathlon.
Equipment that helps aid in plyometric training.
A device, usually portable and electronic or electromechanical, that counts each step a person takes by detecting the motion of the person's hands or hips.
A rope used for exercises and children's games that involve jumping over the usually twirling rope each time it reaches its lowest point.
Sliding disc pad designed for abdominal (core) strength floor exercises.
Device that helps keep track of calories.
A classifier for items in “Exercise & Fitness Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A large, heavy, solid ball thrown and caught for exercise.
Sandbags designed for weight training and general fitness activities.
Box platforms designed for plyometric exercises like box jumps or step ups.
Equipment that helps support inversion therapy.
Garment made from waterproof fabric designed to make the wearer sweat profusely.
Wraps that are wrapped around the body to help increase core body temperature that helps aid to weight loss.

A resistance band is an elastic band used for strength training. They are also commonly used in physical therapy, specifically by convalescents of muscular injuries, including cardiac rehab patients to allow slow rebuilding of strength.
A 4-inch to 12-inch raised platform for the user to step up, around, and down from the platform in different patterns to boost your heart rate and breathing and strengthen your muscles.
Pads designed to cover the weight bar and provide a cushion between the body and bar.
Exercise mat. A piece of material to perform exercise on. Exercise mats are used in a gym or at home to perform exercise.
A piece of equipment that is flat on one side and a dome on the other. Both sides allow the user to perform exercises that engage a variety of muscles.
Fitness weights that strap onto the ankle.

Grippers, sometimes called hand grippers, are primarily used for testing, and increasing the strength of the hands; this specific form of grip strength has been called crushing grip, which has been defined as meaning the prime movers are the four fingers, rather than the thumb.
Thick, heavy ropes designed for a wide range of motion and upper-body strength training.

A foam roller is a lightweight, cylindrical tube of compressed foam. It may be used for many reasons, including increasing flexibility, reducing soreness, and eliminating muscle knots. Foam rolling is a method of self-myofascial release.
Small, mostly disposable, packets placed inside gloves and footwear to keep hands, feet, and toes warm.
An elongated oval-shaped ball used in the sport of rugby football.
Equipment used to maintain a sports field.
Net used in various sport goals.
Structure that is placed at each end of the playing field used for scoring in athletic competition.
Vertical posts used for sport goals.
A classifier for items in “Equestrian Care & Sport Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A piece of equipment used to keep the saddle in place.
A liquid or gel that is applied to the horse's body and helps with cooling down, pain, stiffness, or soreness.
A fabric pad or blanket used on the day for riding to help protect your horse's back from friction.
Blanket or sheet used to shield horses from varying weather conditions and climates.
A hooked implement used to remove foreign objects from a hoof.
A cover used on the eyes, jaw and ears of the horse to help protect from flies and other insects
A device that connects to a vehicle or another type of load.
A light frame or ring that holds the foot of a rider, attached to the saddle by a strap.
A piece material that fits in a horse's mouth and aids in the communication between the horse and the rider.
Bags attached to a horse's saddle.
Repellent specially made for horses and designed to keep flies away.
A piece of equipment used to direct the horse's head and control the speed.  The overall bit is connected to the bridle and reins.
Metal riding aids worn on the heel of riding boots that allow directing the movement of a horse or any animal you are riding.
A big piece of wood or fiberglass covered with leather that goes on a horse's back to provide comfort and security to the rider.
Tool used in horse grooming that removes sweat and/ or excess hair.
Tack used to lead or tie up your horse.
A piece of equestrian tack designed to control a horse's head carriage.
Lightweight sheet intended to cover the horse and act as a barrier to insects, pests, and UV light.
A protective boot or wrap designed to prevent a horse's lower leg or hoof from experiencing trauma.
A short type of whip without a lash used in horse riding.
A device used by riders to guide and signal their horse.
Treats that are intended to be given to horses.
An open-front canvas top for the cockpit of a boat, usually supported by a metal frame.
A non-electric device mounted on the boat's transom has a vane that takes a signal from the wind.
Seats of a boat.

A rope, wire or webbing strung from a ship's bow to stern to which a safety harness can be tethered, allowing a crewmember to move about the deck safely when there is risk of falling or being swept overboard.
Ventilation for a sealed part of a boat and metal plates, which are placed around the furnace of a marine engine in order to protect the deck
A machine used on ships that is used to let-out and heave-up equipment such as a ship's anchor or a fishing trawl.
A circular flotation device attached to a rope that can be thrown to a person who is in the water and needs assistance.
Device generally used for walking, running, or climbing while staying in the same place.

A stationary bicycle is a device used as exercise equipment for indoor cycling. It includes a saddle, pedals, and some form of handlebars arranged as on a bicycle. A stationary bicycle is usually a special-purpose exercise machine resembling a bicycle without wheels.
An exercise machine with a sliding seat, used to strengthen the muscles used in rowing.

An elliptical trainer or cross-trainer is a stationary exercise machine used to stair climb, walk, or run without causing excessive pressure to the joints, hence decreasing the risk of impact injuries. For this reason, people with some injuries can use an elliptical to stay fit, as the low impact affects them little.
Treadmill component that you walk or run on. It moves while staying in the same place, and it dictates the speed you should walk or run, depending on the treadmill settings.
An exercise machine that replicates the motion of walking up stairs.
Motor that runs a treadmill.
Machines require simultaneous arm and leg movement that mimics skiing.
Cushions that prevent a boat from being damaged by rubbing/impacting a dock when the boat's tied up or from being damaged by contact with another boat when multiple boats are tied/rafted together.
A ladder affixed to a dock that allows for climbing in and out of the water
A set of steps affixed to a dock that allows one to descend into the water.
Anchoring fixtures that are used to secure vessels to docks.
A long stick with a pointed and hooked tip, used as a docking and undocking aid.
A storage container for dock and boating accessories.
Boat-mounted device designed for securing a rope or line.
A device, normally made of metal, used to secure a vessel to the bed of a body of water to prevent the craft from drifting.
An object used to protect your boat against damage in the event that it hits a dock.
Ropes and lines used to moor vessels to a dock.
A floating structure which is used to moor vessels while in deep or shallow water.
A classifier for items in “Bowling Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Sets of products for the sport of bowling.
Alley is where the bowler can play the sport of bowling in the house.

Pool – played on a table with 6 pockets with 9 to 15 object balls plus an additional cue ball. The number of balls depends on the type of pool you’re playing.
Snooker – played on a table that has 6 pockets. Snooker tables are larger than pool tables but the pockets are smaller than a pool tables’. Snooker is played with 15 pink numberless balls, 6 numbered object balls, and 1 cue ball.

A trampoline is a recreational device or apparatus that consists of a strong, flexible fabric stretched tightly over a steel frame with coiled springs. It is designed to provide a bouncy surface for jumping and performing acrobatic movements.

The trampoline's fabric, often referred to as the jumping mat, is attached to the frame using numerous springs. These springs allow the mat to stretch and rebound when weight is applied, resulting in a bouncing effect. The frame is typically made of steel and is supported by legs or a sturdy base to ensure stability.

Trampolines are commonly used for fun and entertainment, particularly by children and families in backyards or dedicated trampoline parks. Jumping on a trampoline can provide a sense of exhilaration and can be used for recreational activities, exercise, or even training for gymnastics or acrobatics.

Safety measures, including safety nets, padding, and proper supervision, are often recommended to prevent accidents and injuries while using trampolines. It is important to follow safety guidelines and use trampolines responsibly to minimize the risk of accidents.
