Items sold together that allow you to play the game of jai alai.

Racquet sport that combines elements of tennis and squash. It is typically played in doubles on an enclosed court, which is smaller than a tennis court and surrounded by glass walls. The game is played with solid paddles and a pressurized ball. The rules are similar to tennis, with players taking turns to hit the ball over the net and trying to score points by making the ball bounce twice on the opponent's side of the court. Padel is a popular sport in Spain and Latin America, and its popularity is growing in other parts of the world as well.
The spherical object used in pickleball.

A small piece of silicon rubber that is inserted into a tennis racquet's string bed near the throat of the racquet. This product is designed to reduce the amount of vibration from the strings after you make contact with the ball.
Posts that hold the racquet net in place.
Grips used on racquets.
A classifier for items in “Racquet Sports Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Balls used in a racquet based sport.
A short-handled bat used in pickleball.

Type of ball used in the sport of padel. It is similar to a tennis ball but has some differences. Padel balls are usually made of rubber and have a slightly lower bounce compared to a tennis ball. This is because the padel court is smaller and enclosed, so a lower bouncing ball helps to keep the game more controlled and allows for longer rallies. The pressure inside a padel ball is also lower than a tennis ball, which further affects its bounce. Padel balls are designed to be durable and provide good performance on the padel court.
Bag or covers for racquets.
The strings form a woven network inside the head (or "hoop") of the racquet.
Nets that are used for racquet sports.
A tool used to install strings into a racquet through a process called racquet stringing.
Balls used in the sport of polo.
The equipment used to hit a ball during the game of polo.
Tank used to hold compressed air or nitrogen for propulsion of paintballs in a paintball gun.
A classifier for items in “Paintball Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Device Used To Fill Co2 or HPA Paintball Tank.
A collection of components that includes a paintball gun/marker.
A paintball tank that is not mounted on a paintball gun.
Cover for protection or embellishment of a paintball tank or bottle.
An air gun used in the shooting sport of paintball, and the main piece of paintball equipment.
Item worn to carry spare paintballs and other accessories that you might need during the game.
Paintballs are round, thin-skinned gelatin capsules with colored liquid Inside them used in paintball guns.
Device to help balance the paintball gun by allowing the tank to mount forward and down.
A valve that regulates the air pressure of a paintball gun.
A device that holds and feeds paintballs into the marker or gun.
Weapons used in the various forms of martial arts.
A case that holds martial arts belts for display.
A stand to hold martial arts weapons.
A belt that indicates the level/rank of a martial artist.
Targets used for the practice of martial arts.
A case that holds various martial arts weapons.
A large pad with straps that a trainer/partner holds for the person who is practicing kicks.
A classifier for items in “Martial Arts Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.

productType.productTypeName: Martial Arts Hand Targets & Focus Mitts
productType.description: Hand targets/mitts are handheld pads that are used when training for martial arts. Some can be attached to a freestanding bag.
Sticks that are used in certain forms of martial arts like Arnis/Kali/Escrima.
A large kite used in kiteboarding.
Handheld bars connected to a kite via control lines, used to guide and control a kite while kiteboarding or landboarding.
A board that a rider is secured to that will be pulled along the water surface by a kite.
A classifier for items in “Kiteboarding Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A wheeled board with large, tough wheels that is pulled along by a kite, similar to kiteboarding.
Lines connecting control bars to a kite, allowing a rider to be pulled by the wind in kiteboarding or landboarding.
Carts primarily used for transporting large animals over more flat terrain.
A device that allows hunters to sit high up in a tree, obscuring them from wildlife and providing greater views of an area.
Items that make sounds or lure animals into an area or trap.
Devices that amplify ambient sound so you can hear your surroundings better than you could with your naked ears.
A pad adhered to the buttstock of a rifle to diminish felt recoil.
Used to display a hunting body or part taken from a hunted animal.
A large feeding apparatus used to draw in and retain game on property or land.
Devices used to indicate where particular game might be in the wilderness.
A classifier for items in “Hunting Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Used to assist hunters in scaling a tree to enter a tree stand.
Various items that diminish or remove the scents expelled by humans, making it harder for animals to detect them.
Devices used to lift up or hold a game carcass off the ground for processing.
Scents used to attract an animal to a hunter's location.
Belts or bags used to hold or store game when hunting.
A concealment device or shelter for hunters or gamekeepers, designed to reduce the chance of detection by animals.
Hunting accessories that help camouflage a hunter.
Bait, feed, or food material that is designed to attract game wildlife for hunting purposes.
Devices used to monitor wildlife activity in a certain area or on a particular trail.
Cage traps are designed to catch live animals in a cage. They are usually baited, sometimes with food bait and sometimes with a live "lure" animal.
Items used in the demarcation of areas, valuable to assist hunters in knowing where they are, where they've been, etc.
A decoy used to mimic the animal being hunted.
Gymnastics Skill Shapes are the props for execution of acrobatic movements such as rolls, twists, handsprings, or somersaults on floor mats or on the ground.
Bar apparatus used in gymnastics.
A specially prepared exercise surface.
A classifier for items in “Gymnastics Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A Gymnastics Ribbon is an apparatus composed of a handle, a ribbon, and attachment, that is used during a floor performance.
A piece of rhythmic gymnast equipment similar to bowling pins or bottles.
Devices that are worn on the hands of gymnasts when performing on various apparatus.
Gymnastics Rings are consisting of two small circles that are suspended by straps from an overhead support and grasped by the gymnast while performing various exercises
A Gymnastics Pommel Horse is an artistic gymnastics apparatus
Long, skinny rectangular gymnastics apparatus raised from the floor on a leg or stand at both ends.

Handball is a sports equipment used in the Handball sport which is a team sport in which two teams of seven players each pass a ball using their hands with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the other team.
A case that holds ammunition.
A small firearm designed to be held in one hand.

Device used to hold or restrict the undesired movement of a handgun on a person's body, most commonly in a location where it can be easily withdrawn for immediate use. Holsters are often attached to a belt or waistband, but they may be attached to other locations of the body.

A Gun rod is a firearm maintenance tool that can be used to clean the inside (bore) of a gun's barrel and is made in different sizes for use on different barrel lengths, calibers, and gauges. It is a sturdy, long, thin, straight rod typically made of metal, rigid plastic, or carbon fiber, and usually has a handle at one end for gripping and threadings at the other end for attaching cleaning accessories.

Object installed at the business end of a shot gun barrel that constricts a gun's shot charge to hold it together longer before the shot spreads, thus giving a denser shot pattern at longer range than an open choke or no choke at all.
Lubricant used for a firearm.
A pouch meant for holding and carrying guns
A weapon mount is an assembly or mechanism used to hold a weapon (typically a gun) onto a platform in order for it to function at maximum capacity.
A tool or a device used to load ammunition by manually assembling each of the components.

A strap or harness designed to allow a shooter to conveniently carry a gun on his/her body, and/or to aid in greater hit probability by allowing the firearm to be better braced and stabilized during aiming.
A portable container used to hold all the necessities a shooter needs for a day at the range.
Brush used to clean firearms.
A portable device that keeps your gun steady when firing.
A machine that slings clay pigeons into the sky.
Projectiles you load into a sling shot for ammo.
A saucer-shaped piece of baked clay or other material thrown up in the air from a trap as a target for shooting.
Ammunition feeding device of a firearm.
A collection of components used to clean firearms.

A revolver is a firearm that has a cylinder with a number of chambers. These chambers are designed to be manually loaded with cartridges of the appropriate caliber and then, as the cylinder rotates into position under the hammer, the trigger can be pulled, releasing the hammer causing the cartridge to be fired.

A handgun is a short-barrelled firearm that can be held and used with one hand. The two most common handgun sub-types in use today are revolvers and semi-automatic pistols, although other handgun-types such as derringers and machine pistols also see infrequent usage.
The metal tube through which a projectile or shot charge is fired.
Cases used to store or transport firearms.
Attached for a long gun where a sling can be affixed.
A single package that includes both a gun stock and firearm barrel.
A small toy or weapon that you can use for shooting small projectiles. A slingshot works like a small catapult, with rubber strips holding a pocket where the projectile sits.
Traditionally, a short break-action shotgun chambered in 20-gauge or . 410 bore is the standard for dispatching serpents.
The attachment at the end of a firearm cleaning rod. They hold a cleaning patch in place while you push the rod through the bore.
Tools used to work on or gunsmith Air Guns.
A long-barreled firearm designed to shoot a straight-walled cartridge known as a shotshell.
A gun rack, rifle rack or arm rack is a rack for storing firearms such as rifles and pistols.
A telescopic sight on a rifle.
The tool or device used to impart a desired shape form or finish to the cartridge when reloading or manufacturing ammunition.
Solvents used to clean firearms.
Devices used to secure a firearm.
Replacement components for a firearm's handle that improve the fitment of the firearm in the operator's hand.
The material fired, scattered, dropped, or detonated from any weapon or weapon system.
A gun safe is a safe designed for storing one or more firearms and/or ammunitions.
Portable attachment that help support and steady a long gun when firing.
Gun cleaning solutions are chemical-based formulas that work to remove built-up contaminants such as copper and carbon fouling in guns.
A missile designed to be fired from a gun.
A firearm that uses pneumatic pressure to fire a projectile.
A part of a long gun that provides structural support, to which the barrel, action, and firing mechanism are attached.
Devices used to assist in the loading of ammunition into a firearm magazine.
A gun, especially one fired from shoulder level, having a long spirally grooved barrel intended to make a bullet spin and thereby have greater accuracy over a long distance.
A spotting scope is a compact lightweight portable telescope optimized for detailed observation of distant objects.

Rail systems on firearms are straight mounting brackets (usually made of strips of metal or polymer) on the gun's receiver, handguard or fore-end stock to allow sliding/variable-position attachment of optical sights and accessories such as tactical lights, laser sights, vertical/angled foregrips and bipods.
Tools or accessories used in gunsmithing.

Golf Club Bags are designed to hold golf clubs as well as all the accessories a golfer could possibly need - tees, balls, towels, shoes, gloves, etc. They usually have shoulder straps, and occasionally a kick stand to hold it upright. There are bags especially designed for travel, and depending on size, can hold anywhere from 1 to 14 clubs.
Irons are clubs with a solid, all-metal head featuring a flat angled face, and a shorter shaft and more upright lie angle than a wood, for ease of access.
Sets of products used to fix or repair golf club grips.
Device used to measure the distance on a golf course.
The long tubes that connect the club's grip to the club's head.

Golf Cleaning Tools are items that are used to clean golf clubs and some accessories. NOTE: This PT does not include Golf Divot Tools or Golf Towels, as these have their own PTs. If the cleaning brush comes with other items, like a towel or divot tool, use the retail packaging attribute to capture that info (ex: Kit, Set, Gift Set, etc)
Specially designed carts that carry a golf bag and are manually pushed or pulled across the golf course, though some come equipped with a small motor for extra power.
A towel with an attached caribiner or grommet for a caribiner so that it can easily attach to a golf bag.
Shoes designed for a golfer.
A classifier for items in “Golf Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A long-distance club meant to drive the ball off a tee a great distance down the fairway towards the hole. They generally have a large head and a long shaft for maximum club speed.
Mat used to practice the hitting of golf balls.
Nets designed to absorb the impact of a golf ball, making it the ideal home solution for practicing golf drives
Socks that allow the golfer to warm up before rounds by adding weight to the club for practice swings.
Flag used to denote where a hole is located on a green.
Device used to organize golf clubs.

Golf Balls are special balls designed to be used in the game of golf. Under the rules of golf, a golf ball has a mass no more than 1.620 oz (45.9 g), has a diameter not less than 1.680 inches (42.7 mm), and performs within specified velocity, distance, and symmetry limits.
A stand used in golf sport to support and elevate a golf ball prior to striking.

Golf Club Head Covers are protective sleeves that are meant to fit over the head of clubs while they are not in use. They work to protect golf clubs from unintended damage. Head covers prevent the clubs from banging around and clanking into each other while walking, driving in a golf cart, being carried or simply sitting in the bag in between rounds.

Golf Club Grips are the part of the golf club that is located at its top. Golfers use it to actually hold the club in their hands. It is often made from a single hollow piece of rubber that is slid over the top portion of the shaft of the club. NOTE:This PT does not include Golf Grip Repair Kits, which is its own PT. If the item includes products for the "repair" or "regripping" of a Golf Club Grip but is predominantly grips, keep it in the Golf Club Grips PT and use the retail packaging attribute to capture that info (ex: Kit, Set, Gift Set, etc)

A set of implements with heavy wooden or metal head on a slender shaft used to hit the ball in golf. A modern set of golf clubs typically consists of three woods (the 1-driver, 3, and 5), at least 1 hybrid (3H) seven irons (4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and PW), and a putter. This gives you a total of twelve clubs.
A small hand tool with two protruding prongs used to tighten or remove spikes from the bottom of a golf shoe
Organizers to keep golf items organized in a trunk.

A mixture of a fairway wood and an iron, but while the center of gravity on a fairway wood falls toward the back of the clubhead, a hybrid golf club has its center of gravity toward the front of the clubhead.

A global positioning device that can help the user navigate the golf course as well as record and save your golf scores and statistics. Golf GPS systems include a map of the course, your location on the course and precise distances between you, your ball and the hole.

Wedges are a subclass of irons with greater loft than the numbered irons (generally starting at 47°–48° of loft, above the 9-iron's 44°–45°), and other features such as high-mass club heads and wide soles that allow for easier use in tricky lies.

A long-distance club meant to drive the ball off the turf a great distance down the fairway towards the hole. They generally have a large head and a long shaft for maximum club speed.  The club head and shaft are shorter than drivers.
Putters are a special class of clubs with a loft not exceeding ten degrees, designed primarily to roll the ball along the grass, generally from a point on the putting green toward the hole.
Items that mark the place on a putting green where a golf ball is lifted.
Devices used to retrieve lost or misplaced golf balls from water hazards, deep rough or even the occasional sand trap.

Originally golf umbrellas are designed to protect golfers and their bags in the rain. The golf umbrella size is much bigger than a normal umbrella, generally golf umbrellas have a rib length between 26 inches and 34 inches while normal umbrellas the rib length is only from 21 inches to 25 inches.
Tool used to repair divots on the golf course.
The part of the golf club that comes into contact with the ball.
A training aid that helps to a golfer's swing.
A hockey puck is either an open or closed disk used in a variety of sports and games.
Floor Hockey Carts holds multiple sticks in the upright position and also includes a large detachable bag for balls, pucks and more.
Floor hockey sticks feature a shatterproof, semi-rigid shaft that is reinforced with a fiberglass tube for routine junior high play.
Balls used for the sport of floor hockey. They are typically made of plastic and orange in color.
Goals used for the sport of floor hockey. This is a piece of equipment that indicates the “goal” area for players to hit as a target to score.
Floor Hockey Sets include sticks, a plastic ball or puck, shoes, nets, gloves, shin guards, elbow pads, shoulder pads, helmets/face shields, mouth pieces and jerseys.
The football girdle is a thin sleeve of material worn under football pants that has stitched pockets to hold various pads:
Objects utilized to mark the yardage on a football field.
A grease or strip applied under the eyes to reduce glare.
Football pants are specially designed to hold a player's leg padding and ensure they can run freely.
A shirt with integrated pads worn between a football players skin and pads.

Football gloves protect player's hands from a variety of potentially dangerous situations. Their padding can help prevent injuries to hands and fingers or stop them getting damaged by snagging on an opponent's equipment.
A wristband with windowed compartments to store plays, field positions or signals that a player can reference during a game.
An open-meshed fabric twisted, knotted, or woven together at regular intervals used by football quarterbacks to practice their throws.
Football Kicking Cages are used for kickers to practice. The cage captures the ball and prevents the kicker from having to retrieve it.
Shoulder pads are a piece of protective equipment that covers the shoulders, chest, and upper back.

The primary function of a football visor is protection. While some players wear visors temporarily to prevent damage to an existing injury, other players wear them permanently to prevent new injuries. A football visor protects the player's eyes from getting stricken by fingers or feet when colliding with other players.
Football Pant Belts are a piece of fabric used to secure football pants in place.
A football knee pad is a leather, foam rubber, etc., that is worn by football player to protect the knee.
Football neck rolls have forever been part of the game, and a player's armor out on the field. The main purpose of a neck roll is to cradle and hold the neck in proper place.
An oval ball used in the sport of football typically made of leather or plastic and filled with compressed air.
Protective equipment placed into an integrated pocket of football players pants inn the front of their thighs.
A thin fabric belt that is adjustable and wraps around a player's waist. It will have a few flags hanging off of the belt which can either be pulled off or grabbed to release the belt.
A football towel are designed to hang from a belt, typically with Velcro or hook & loop fasteners.  They are typically a highly absorbent, quick drying material.
A football chin strap secures a players helmet to the head by going over the chin and snapping to the helmet.
Football players wear hand warmers to ensure that their hands are at optimal temperature for throwing and catching the football.

A football back plate (sometimes referred to as a back flap) is a piece of safety equipment that attaches to a player's shoulder pads that helps protect the lower back. Back plates connect to the shoulder pads using an attachment strap and hardware/screws.
Helmet stickers, also known as reward decals and pride stickers, are stickers that are affixed to a player's helmet.
Football flak jackets, otherwise known as rib protectors, are pieces of protective equipment that are attached to the shoulder pads and wrapped around the abdomen/rib area.
Football Practice Jerseys are meant to be used during drills and scrimmage games, and are typically lightweight, simple mesh jerseys with solid colors, to easily determine teams and positions.
A classifier for items in “Football Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.

The football helmet is a piece of protective equipment used mainly in gridiron football. It consists of a hard plastic shell with thick padding on the inside, a face mask made of one or more plastic-coated metal bars, and a chinstrap.
A kicking tee is used to give a ball some clearance from the ground and allows a secure holding of it for a player to kick. A kicking holder is used to hold a ball in position to be kicked.

Football cones are often used for speed and agility drills, which are essential for players at every position and skill level. Football cones can also be used simply as zone markers. A pylon in football is a small orange rectangular marker that is placed in each of the corners of both end zones, in an area considered out-of-bounds.
Football machines are designed by professional engineers intent on creating devices that send footballs flying high into the air, simulating actual passes, punts, kickoffs, long snaps and more.
A football practice dummy, sometimes called a blocking dummy or blocking bag, is a heavy bag that simulates a real player.
In gridiron football, the face mask is the part of the helmet that directly covers the face.
A sled with an upright padded dummy used for blocking, pushing and basic football practice.
A fish scale, a type of often hand-held hanging spring scale on which a fisherman hangs a fish to measure its weight.
Usually a scented, oil-based liquid or gel that is applied to fishing lures or baits.
Carries your rod while traveling.
A pole with a sharp hook on the end that is used to stab a large fish and then lift the fish into the boat or onto shore.
A storage solution to keep your lures protected and orangized.

An artificial fly or fly lure is a type of fishing lure, usually used in the sport of fly fishing (although they may also be used in other forms of angling). In general, artificial flies are an imitation of natural food sources that fly fishers present to their target species of fish while fly fishing. Artificial flies are constructed by fly tying, in which furs, feathers, thread or any of very many other materials are tied onto a fish hook.

A fishing net is a net used for fishing. Nets are devices made from fibers woven in a grid-like structure. Some fishing nets are also called fish traps, for example fyke nets. Fishing nets are usually meshes formed by knotting a relatively thin thread.
A fishing flasher is a fish attractant 'plat' that attaches above the lure and has a narrow diagonal front end which causes it to spin.
Equipment needed for spearfishing. Examples are: wetsuits, rash guards, gloves, booties, free diving fins, weight belt, spearfishing knife, dive computer.
A kit that includes all of the necessary fly tying tools and fly tying materials to tie your own flies.
A fish trap is a trap used for fishing. Fish traps can have the form of a fishing weir or a lobster trap. Some fishing nets are also called fish traps, for example fyke nets.
A small, lightweight inflatable fishing craft which anglers use to fish from.

A tip-up is a device used while ice fishing to suspend live or frozen bait at a set depth through a hole drilled in the ice with an auger, and detect when a fish strikes, without having to be in contact with this piece of gear. When a fish does take the bait, a flag "tips up" or the flag can "tip down" to signal the angler that a fish has taken his bait. Because the angler does not need to stay with his line and can see that the flag at a distance, he or she is able to cover a larger area than with just an ice fishing rod.
A fishing dodger is a fish attractant 'plate' that attaches above the lure and is designed to swing back and forth like a pendulum (instead of spinning).
Boat designed to be used to catch fish in the sea, or on a lake or river.
Belts used to support the fishing rod as well as the back of the fisherman when catching larger fish.
Used for removing hooks, crimping weights, constructing leaders, cutting line, and everything in between, there's hardly a job a good pair of fishing pliers can't tackle when it comes to fishing.
A leader is simply a length of material that connects your fly line to your fly. Tippet is a specific gauge monofilament line that is attached to the end of the leader, to which you tie the fly.

A combo is a matched rod and reel set, configured for a specific type of fishing. West Marine offers baitcasting combos, conventional combos and spinning combos. The selection varies from really basic set-ups to top quality packages with excellent reels and quality rods by Penn, Shimano and others.
A device used while fishing using the trolling method, which places a lure at the desired depth.
Fixed mounts installed in the gunwale of your boat designed to hold a fishing rod.
Buoys used to show the location of underwater gear such as a crab pot or a hazard such as a rock, while regulatory buoys mark a specific area like a slow speed zone.

Gear that is attached to the end of a fishing line is called terminal tackle. This includes hooks, leaders, swivels, sinkers, floats, split rings and wire, snaps, beads, spoons, blades, spinners and clevises to attach spinner blades to fishing lures, and tools that make it easy to tie knots.
A fishing float (or bobber) attaches to the line and serves multiple purposes: it suspends terminal tackle above the lakebed, it acts as a strike indicator, etc.
Live composting worms that are intended to improve garden soil quality by breaking down organic waste.
A tool for catching fish either by impaling them in the mouth or, more rarely, by snagging the body of the fish.
Scoop or skimming tool designed to remove ice from a fishing hole.
A box designed for fishing equipment
A type of artificial fishing bait which is designed to attract a fish's attention. The lure uses movement, vibration, flash and color to bait fish.
Any substance used to attract and catch fish, e.g. on the end of a fishing hook, or inside a fish trap.
A cord, generally resemble a long, thin string, and vary in material, used or made for angling.

A fishing sinker or knoch is a weight used in conjunction with a fishing lure or hook to increase its rate of sink, anchoring ability, and/or casting distance. Fishing sinkers may be as small as 1 gram for applications in shallow water, and even smaller for fly fishing applications, or as large as several pounds or considerably more for deep sea fishing. They are formed into nearly innumerable shapes for diverse fishing applications. Environmental concerns surround the usage of lead and other materials in fishing sinkers.
Table or large cutting board surface designed for easy cleaning (i.e. filleting) of fish.
A classifier for items in “Fishing Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Fly fishing tools would capture a lot of the smaller products such as line straighteners, fishing forceps, line cutters, and knot tyers specifically meant for fly fishing.
A trap that uses bait to catch fish.
Live insects primarily used for animal food (e.g. live crickets) and gardening uses (e.g. live ladybugs, praying mantises).
Materials such as beads, bodies, braid, chenille, cones, dubbing, eyes, feathers, fur, hair, legs, rib, shanks, synthetics, thread, tinsel, tubing, wire, and yarn to create your own fishing flies.
Safety handles with spiked tips or picks used to escape after falling through ice.
A storage device designed for quick and easy rod removal.

Fish Holders are a device that features a handle with a locking system that clamps down on the inside and outside of the fish's bottom lip. The Fish Holder makes it easier to control the fish while landing it and easier to hold.

A fishing rod is a long, flexible rod used by fishermen to catch fish. At its simplest, a fishing rod is a simple stick or pole attached to a line ending in a hook (formerly known as an angle, hence the term angling).
A portable shed placed on a frozen lake to provide shelter during ice fishing.
Sharpening steels are used to sharpen fish hooks while on the water.
A sleeveless piece of equipment with multiple pockets designed to store fishing tackle and accessories.
A cylindrical device attached to a fishing rod used in winding and stowing line.
Instrument used to locate fish underwater by detecting reflected pulses of sound energy, as in sonar.

A hockey net is attached to the back of the frame to catch balls that enter the goal and also to prevent the ball from entering it from behind. Hockey nets can come in different dimensions depending on how deep at ground level and at crossbar level the goal is.

Goalie kickers greatly helps during defending the post for the goalies. Kickers aid in posing a hurdle to the incoming ball from hitting the post. Kickers also offer a sturdy environment for the goalies on the field.

A hockey stick is a piece of sports equipment used by the players in all the forms of hockey to move the ball or puck either to push, pull, hit, strike, flick, steer, launch or stop the ball/puck during play with the objective being to move the ball/puck around the playing area.
Field hockey gloves are made to allow players to play with maximum function in their hands and wrists. Gloves are made up of a hard plastic shell and foam to help absorb any stick or ball impact.

The field hockey goalie pants of a hockey goalkeeper is versatile. They offer a thicker, more substantial protection in the "ball facing" areas (thigh, groin, waist), and they are wider to help cover more of the net.
The grip help players to hold the hockey stick with their hands.
Hockey shin guards protect a vulnerable area of a player's legs from slashes, balls, and other skates.
Field hockey goggles help prevent injury while allowing clear visibility.

This starter kit includes a helmet, shoulder pads/chest protector, safety glasses, mouthguards, gloves, masks, elbow pads, padded shorts, a 'jock' athletic protector, stick, shin pads and a neck guard.

A field hockey ball is made of solid plastic and is extremely durable. It may also have a cork core in some cases. Outdoor field hockey balls are usually dimpled to maintain a constant pace when playing on turf or wet surfaces.

Goalie hand protectors offer significant advantages and are strongly recommended for the serious goalkeeper. They provide better grip on the ball when making saves, protect and cushion fingers and palms.
A fencing lame is an electrically conductive jacket worn by foil and sabre fencers in order to define the scoring area
A fencing epee is one of three fencing weapons. It is the largest weighing approximately 27 ounces. The weapon's blade is triangular in shape and quite stiff to bend.
A weapon with a long piece of thin metal with a handle and a guard.

A fencing sabre is one of three fencing weapons. The blade is V-Shaped with the point folded over to form a button. This weapon is used for thrusting and cutting with the edge and back of the blade. A sabre is the quickest, most aggressive style of fencing.
Fencing foil parts include a pommel, grip, guard and blade. These parts are used in two types of foils used in modern fencing
A molded plastic sport bra that widens to protect chest
Parts for fencing epee to include the tip, the blade, the wire and the guard.
A foil is one of three fencing weapons, it is lighter weighing less and a pound, is flexible with a quadrangular in shape.

Body cord serves as the connection between a fencer and reel of wire that is part of a system for electrically detecting that the weapon has touched the opponent.  They are made of three wires with connectors on each end.
The parts to a fencing Sabre are: The grip, guard and blade

A dog sled or dog sleigh is a sled pulled by one or more sled dogs used to travel over ice and through snow. Numerous types of sleds are used, depending on their function. They can be used for dog sled racing.
Lines are used for harness work with single or multiple dog teams pulling bikes, scooters, carts or sleds.
A kit with the basic necessities to play disc golf.
A target used in disc golf.

A disc that is designed to have the slowest speeds and the thinnest rims. These characteristics allow for less deviation, creating more of a straight path and not flying too far when you don't make the shot.
A disc used in the sport of disc golf to make approach shots.

A disc that is designed for higher speed throws and thus the most potential distance to be had. The wider rim and sharper outside edge of a driver allows the disc to cut through the air more efficiently than the other types of discs.
A classifier for items in “Disk Golf Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A disc used in the sport of disc golf to make mid-range shots.
A diving suit is a garment or device designed to protect a diver from the underwater environment.
Diving Backpacks is the perfect dive bag for all diving gear features with compartments and water proofing, so it can hold your fins, goggles, snorkel, beach toys, towels, and a change of clothes
Underwater scooters also known as Diver Propulsion Vehicles is an item of diving equipment used by scuba divers to increase range underwater.
A pressure regulator that controls the pressure of breathing gas for diving.
Diving Mask Slap Straps are for unbeatable comfort, eliminates pulled hair, and distributes pressure more evenly allowing for a better mask seal.
A classifier for items in “Diving Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Diving Mask Defogger is a solution to reduce the surface tension smoothing out the droplets on Diving Lens/mask

A Divers carry gauges that display information such as remaining cylinder pressure, current depth, elapsed dive time, and direction of travel. Diving gauge is a pressure gauge that displays the equivalent depth below the free surface in water.
A screw-down shut off valve fitted to the neck of a scuba cylinder to control breathing gas flow to and from the pressure vessel and to provide a connection with the scuba regulator or filling whip.
Communication devices used by scuba divers.
Reels are a crucial safety item used to keep you in contact with surface support, guide you back to a known starting point, or to position you during search and retrieve operations.

The fundamental use of Diving Clips used by divers in underwater to hook apparatus. For example, a clip on your stage bottle used in cold water with dry gloves, or a massive one on a backup torch in the tropics.
Diving Kits are the equipments used by underwater divers to make diving activities possible, easier, safer and/or more comfortable.
The Diving Octopus is a secondary regulator as a backup in case of emergencies. If your diving regulator fails (or that of your dive buddy), you know that you have your backup secondary regulator.

Diving Buoyancy Compensator is a type of diving equipment which is worn by divers to establish neutral buoyancy underwater and positive buoyancy at the surface and therefore his depth, during a dive, and it attaches the tank to the diver.
A dive computer takes depth and time information and applies it to a decompression model to track the dissolved nitrogen in your body during a dive.
Diving Decompression Limit Monitor allows you to check your depth, dive time, bearing (with a compass), and remaining tank time - with a single glance.
A closed and sealed container designed to hold compressed gas for diving.
A flotation device that makes it easy for the user to balance their body in the water face down.
Belts with lead weights on them for diving.
A dart board is the target for the game of darts, in the same vein as the round bullseye target used in archery.
Dart cabinets are designed to hold a dartboard ready for play, while not in play the doors may be closed to hide the board.

Dartboard backboards are heavier duty than surrounds and as such they take a little more effort to install. They are mounted directly to the wall and then your dartboard is mounted onto it. When compared to a dartboard surround, backboards have more opportunity for storage and other accessories such as scoreboards.

The dart's shaft is the part of the dart located between the barrel and the flight, the one that connects these two elements. The shaft, also called a stem, is screwed into the dart's barrel, and holds the flight firmly in place.
A classifier for items in “Dart Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A dart is a small, slender missile that is pointed at one end and usually feathered at the other and is propelled by hand, as in the game of darts.

A dart flight is the small aerodynamic fins at the back of a dart. The primary purpose of a flight is to provide stability for the dart when thrown. Dart flights are usually made of plastic or nylon and come in many shapes and sizes, each having a different effect on your throw.

Dart wallets and dart cases are indispensable dart accessories for both beginners and advanced dart players. With these handy cases, you can safely store, stow and transport your darts to, for example, a match or tournament. The darts, flights and shafts can be stored neatly organised in the dart wallets and dart cases so you always have a good overview of which accessories you still have.

Dart Points are the tip of the dart. Long Dart points come in plastic (soft tip darts) or steel (steel tip darts) versions. Both steel and soft tip darts can be used on "bristle" dart boards (the boards traditionally used with steel darts). Some dart points are removable while others are permanently integrated into the barrel. Darts can also have either fixed points or moveable points. Moveable point darts are constructed in a way that allows the points to retract slightly into the barrels upon impact.
A barre is a stationary handrail that provides support for people during various types of exercise/dance. Barres are used extensively in ballet training and warm up exercises.
A Dance Floor is a flooring surface suitable for dance or sport. They are normally laid on top of, or a part of, a sprung floor to produce a complete dance floor or sports floor.
A classifier for items in “Dancing Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
The mechanism attached to  specially made shoes used to provide maximum traction with the bicycle's pedal.
A set of products designed to repair flat tires on bicycles.
The outer edge of a wheel, holding the tire. It makes up the outer circular design of the wheel on which the inside edge of the tire is mounted.
Covering designed to protect a bicycle from sun, rain, and dirt.

A pannier is a basket, bag, box, or similar container, carried in pairs slung over the sides of a bicycle or motorcycle.
A rack trunk is a storage container mounted to a rack.

Grease generally serves two purposes in a bicycle: Lubricating threads or metal parts that are clamped together. For these applications, any reasonably thick grease should suffice. Lubricating bearings. When the grease next to a bearing in under a load, it no longer acts like a liquid, but like a solid.
A component used to control the gearing mechanisms and select the desired gear ratio of a bicycle.
The steering mechanism, in lieu of a steering wheel, on bicycles or motorcycles.
Sports jersey for cycling.
Rack that rests over the wheel of a bicycle, and is usually mounted somewhere on the fork or frame.
A pair of small supporting wheels fitted on either side of the rear wheel of a child's bicycle.

A device mounted on a bicycle that calculates and displays trip information, similar to the instruments in the dashboard of a car. The computer with display, or head unit, usually is attached to the handlebar for easy viewing.
A classifier for items in “Bicycle Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
The system, or systems, used to suspend the rider and or bicycle in order to insulate them from the roughness of the terrain.

The brake rotor is an iron disc connected to the tire's hub that is used in a disc brake assembly. ... Rotors work hand-in-hand with brake pads to stop your vehicle. When you step on your brake pedal, your vehicle's brake pads are compressed against the rotor creating friction.
A device used to hold bicycles seatpost in a fixed position.
Armless upper body cyclist clothing that can be used as an under or outer layer.
A security device used to deter bicycle theft, generally by fastening the bicycle to a fixed object.
A bicycle-mounted basket for carrying cargo, usually light cargo.
Skin-tight pants specifically designed for wear by cyclists to reduce chafing.
A bicycle fork is the part of a bicycle that holds the front wheel. A fork typically consists of two blades which are joined at the top by a fork crown.
An illumination device attached to bicycles whose purpose above all is to improve the visibility of the bicycle and its rider to other road users under circumstances of poor ambient illumination.
The unicycles classification will initially include any mode of transportation utilizing a single wheel, whether human-powered, motorized, or sporting an engine.
Protective helmet for cyclists.
Athletic shorts specially designed for cycling.
Cases or bags typically used when transporting bicycles.

Frame bags fit inside the frame diamond of your bike, making sure you can carry your personal items without the obstacle of puffy panniers. Bikepacking frame bags give you additional storage space at a relatively low center of gravity, thus allowing the rider to pack heavier items in this location.
Degreasers are designed for heavy-duty cleaning of bike gears and chains.
A saddle that is designed to be put on a bicycle for children to be transported in.

Part of a bicycle that the rider pushes with their foot to propel the vehicle. It provides the connection between the cyclist's foot or shoe and the crank allowing the leg to turn the bottom bracket spindle and propel the bicycle's wheels.
The main component of a bicycle, onto which wheels and other components are fitted.
A stand that lifts the bike off the ground, holds it a comfortable working height and keeps it stable and secure while working on the bike.

A bicycle bell is a percussive signaling instrument mounted on a bicycle for warning pedestrians and other cyclists. A horn is an air operated instrument to make a loud noise as a warning or alert to pedestrians and other cyclists.

A bicycle child seat is a saddle that is designed to be put on a bicycle for a child to be transported in. The most common place for child bicycle seats are in the rear of the bicycle but can also be placed in front of the biker on the handlebar.

A Bicycle child trailer has a towbar that connects to your bike either through the rear wheel axle or through a connector attached to the frame. Child bike trailers typically feature two wheels (rarely, a single wheel), a fabric canopy to protect occupants from the elements, and a bench or hammock-style seat.
The large forward ring on a bicycle that a chain attaches to, in order to transfer energy to a wheel. It consists of one or more sprockets that are driven by the cranks and pedals of the bicycle.
The set of components on a bicycle that provides a rotatable interface between the bicycle fork and the head tube of the bicycle frame.
Shoe covers for cycling typically to provide for wind resistance, water proofing, and high visibility.
A chain that transmits the driving power from the pedals of a bicycle to its rear wheel.
A cylindrical component that holds your cranks together via their axle and lets them freely rotate using a bearing assembly. It sits in the bottom bracket shell, or BB shell.
The component of a bicycle that the rider sits on.
Bicycle accessory designed to hold a cup or can upright and usually mounted on the handlebars or frame. NOTE: this is NOT a Bicycle Bottle Cage.
Device used to affix a water bottle to a bicycle.
A spoke is one of some number of rods radiating from the center of a wheel, connecting the hub with the rim of a bicycle.

An inner tube is an inflatable ring that forms the interior of some pneumatic tires. The tube is inflated with a valve, and fits inside of the casing of the tire. The inflated inner tube provides structural support and suspension, while the outer tire provides grip and protects the more fragile tube.
Sports jacket designed for cyclists.
The cluster of sprockets located on the rear hub of your bike, slotting onto a freehub body and held firmly in place with a threaded cassette lockring.
Guard or component of a bicycle fitted over tires.
A reflective surface that reflects a clear image designed to be mounted to a bike.
The stem is the component on a bicycle that connects the handlebars to the steerer tube of the bicycle fork.

Conversion kits include three major components in order to convert a regular bike into an electric bike. These three components are: an electric motor, a battery, and a controller. ... Conversion kits generally come in three flavors for electric motor placement: front hub motor, rear hub motor, and mid-drive motor.
Hardware hooks or brackets (often mounted on walls or ceilings) that allow for convenient bicycle storage.

Handlebar tape is wrapped around racing-style 'drop' handlebars for grip and comfort, and will wear over time requiring eventual replacement. For many riders the type and quality of their handlebar tape may be little more than an afterthought.
Equipment for holding one or more bikes upright.
Mount accessory designed to hold a bicycle computer in place.
A group of products that consists of cranks, bottom bracket, and chainrings.

A headed cylinder with threading on the inside through part of its length (there is an unthreaded lead-in nearest the ""flats"") that holds a bicycle wheel's rim to each spoke. Traditionally, the nipples fit in holes in the rim, so that the head of the nipple is on the outermost part of the rim, while the other end of the nipple points inwards towards the hub.
A device attached to a bicycle's handlebars to facilitate the rider's grasp.
Fabric cover for a bicycle seat (often called a saddle).

The hub is the central part of your bike's wheels (front and rear), which connects to the wheel's rim via the spokes and through which the axle is fitted, enabling the wheel to freely spin on two sets of bearings.
A wheel designed for a bicycle.
A device for inflating bicycle tires.
An electric bicycle, also known as an e-bike or ebike, is a bicycle with an integrated electric motor used to assist propulsion.
A classifier for items in “Bicycle Parts” that does not have a dedicated PT.

A device on a bicycle that allows the bike to be kept upright without leaning against another object or the aid of a person. A kickstand is usually a piece of metal that flips down from the frame and makes contact with the ground.
A motorless wheeled frame with a hitch system for transporting cargo by bicycle.

An inner tube is an inflatable ring that forms the interior of some pneumatic tires. The tube is inflated with a valve, and fits inside of the casing of the tire. The inflated inner tube provides structural support and suspension, while the outer tire provides grip and protects the more fragile tube.
Skin-tight cycling pants that cover the legs, but are a much lighter material than leggings.
A piece of equipment that makes it possible to ride a bicycle while it remains stationary. They are commonly used to warm up before races, or when riding conditions outside are not favorable.
A complete brake system for bicycles.
Device that holds brake pads and compresses brake pads against wheel or brake rotor for stopping power.
The lever used to activate bicycle brakes.
The mechanism used on bicycles used to move the chain from one sprocket to another.
Cylindrical objects fixed to the of a bike. Pegs are used primarily to perform stunts and tricks.
Tools used to repair or maintain a bicycle.
A vehicle composed of two wheels held in a frame one behind the other, propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars attached to the front wheel.
A tube that extends upwards from the bicycle frame to the saddle.
Dense polished rocks used in Curling.
The curling brush, also known as a "broom" is used to sweep the ice surface in the path of the stone
A classifier for items in “Cricket Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A hard, solid ball used to play cricket. A cricket ball consists of a cork core wound with string then a leather cover stitched on, and manufacture is regulated by cricket law at first-class level.

In cricket, the term wicket has several meanings: It is one of the two sets of three stumps and two bails at either end of the pitch. The fielding team's players can hit the wicket with the ball in a number of ways to get a batter out.
Gloves that are used while playing the sport of cricket.
A specialized piece of equipment used by batters in the sport of cricket to hit the ball, typically consisting of a cane handle attached to a flat-fronted willow-wood blade.
Instrument used measure the amount of time that elapses between its activation and deactivation.
A portable or hand-held, cone-shaped acoustic horn used to amplify a person's voice or other sounds and direct it in a given direction.
Mouth-operated instrument which produces sound from a stream of air used for controlling or bring attention towards the referee or coach during practices and games.
Scoreboard is specially used for displaying scores of each team played between two teams. Timer used to measure time intervals.
A classifier for items in “Coach & Referee Gear” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Scorebooks used to record players details and their score.
A strong fabric woven as a flat strip or tube of varying width and fibers, often used in place of rope when climbing.
A sling is an item of climbing equipment consisting of a tied or sewn loop of webbing.
Bags containing powdered rosin.
A rope that is used in climbing.
A specialized elaboration of the modern ice axe used in ice climbing.
Climbing equipment allows the climber to lower himself, to position himself and to climb back up it.
Equipment utilized by the climber with no belayer used during descending climbing.
A strip of webbing that is fixed above the ground but not stretched tight, used to balance suspended above the ground.
Accessory cord is circular and used for setting up anchors or a rappel, but it is more compact than webbing when hanging on a harness.

A metal spike that is driven into a crack or seam in the climbing surface with a climbing hammer, and which acts as an anchor to either protect the climber against the consequences of a fall or to assist progress in aid climbing.
Variable length tie-offs designed to support body weight during climbing.
Piece of rock climbing gear, generally used for hauling gear when big wall climbing.
Rosin in rock form used to improve grip for all kinds of activities, like climbing and dancing.
Protective gear used during climbing that has moving parts.
Device used for directly ascending a rope, or for facilitating protection with a fixed rope when climbing on very steep mountain terrain.
Mechanical piece of climbing equipment used to control a rope during belaying.
A clinometer is a simple device used to measure angles. It can be used to measure the slope of a specific terrain
Bags used for carrying ropes for climbing.
Pads that help prevent climbers from becoming injured when falling from short heights.
An instrument used to measure the altitude of an object above a fixed level.
A metal loop with a spring-loaded gate used to quickly and reversibly connect components.
A shaped grip that is usually attached to a climbing wall so climbers can grab it or step on it.
A multi-purpose hiking and climbing tool used by mountaineers in both the ascent and descent of routes that involve snow, ice, or frozen conditions.
A classifier for items in “Climbing Accessories” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Toothed metal devices that fit to the soles of specially designed boots to give the wearer secure traction on ice and hard-packed snow.
Protective gear used during climbing that has non-moving parts.
A small pouch filled with climbing chalk, that is attached to a climber's harness removes moisture from the hands and increases friction between the skin and the object.
A decorative ball or tuft of fibrous material shaken by cheerleaders, pom or dance teams, and sports fans during spectator sports.
A stand that is specifically designed to hold speed bags and other punching bags.
Hardware that are specifically intended to hold a punching bag.
The space in which a boxing match occurs.
A heavily padded mitten worn in boxing.
A stuffed or inflated bag, typically cylindrical or pear-shaped, suspended so it can be punched for exercise or training, especially by boxers.
Robes that are worn by boxers as they enter the ring.
Anchors meant to tether a punching/heavy bag to the floor so the bag doesn't swing very much
Cylindrical or pear-shaped platform, suspended so it can be punched for exercise or training, especially by boxers.

Sometimes called Thai Pads, martial arts strike pads are thick durable pads that can be positioned for a wide variety of punches, kicks, and other strikes.  Typically strike pads have three wide straps which allow the trainer to hold the pad at a variety of angles and heights.
Cushioned, often curved pad attached to a glove or mitt and designed to protect a trainer's hands while practicing combinations and other boxing-specific actions (e.g. receiving full-power punches).
A classifier for items in “Boxing Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A dinghie is a type of small boat carried by a larger vessel, usually rowboarts or some have outboard motors
A boat powered exclusively by an engine.
A human powdered watercraft propelled by the action of pedals turning a paddle wheel.
A structure where you park a boat and boating accessories.
A life saving raft appliance on every seagoing merchant or passenger ship.
Inflatable boat is a lightweight boat constructed with this sides and bow make of flexible tubes containing of pressurised gas
A recreational watercraft that are designed to hold only a small number of occupants, who sit/ride or stand on top of the craft, not within the craft as in a boat.
Tanks on ships and boats used to hold fresh water, waste water, and or wash water.
A toilet used on a boat or ship.
Various products used for waste management on ships or boats.
Device that measures depth of water beneath vessels.
Device used to alert Search and Rescue organizations in the event of an emergency.
Self-steering devices for boats.
A large trailer used to carry a boat across land being towed by a vehicle.
Accessory items that are used with a watercraft or assist in the operation of a boat.
Buoy ball is a floatable ball used to mark a point on water.
Mounted basketball systems include a backboard, rim and additional hardware intended to be mounted to your home or garage.
An accessory worn by basketball players made out of nylon and spandex, it extends from the biceps to the wrist. It is sometimes called a shooter sleeve or an arm sleeve.
Pads that wrap around a basketball pole for protection.
Bins or containers used to store basketball supplies.
A spherical ball used in basketball games.
Extra items added to enhance a basketball court.
Devices that can be installed on, above, or under the basketball rim or net, that utilize a mechanism that returns the ball back to the shooter, whether the shooter misses or makes it.
A classifier for items in “Basketball Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A basketball system including a weighted base, short pole and backboard intended to be positioned poolside for play by those in the swimming pool.
In-ground basketball systems range in height from 44 inches to 72 inches. Sturdy, anchor bolt mounting systems allow for easy leveling during installation of your hoop.
A metal circle which the ball must go through in order for a point to be scored. The net is attached to the bottom of the rim and hangs below and behind the rim is the backboard.
A kit with the necessary hardware to mount a basketball backboard to a home or garage.
A net that is designed to be attached to a basketball hoop.
A backboard is a piece of basketball equipment. It is a raised vertical board with an attached basket consisting of a net suspended from a hoop.
Portable basketball systems include a weighted base, pole and backboard that can be moved.
Padding affixed to cover edges and corners of a backboard.
Protective face guards for a catcher.

Designed to protect against foul tips, and missed catches, the catcher's chest protector will have contour padding that fits over the body and secures with adjustable straps on the back. A chest protector needs to be lightweight to provide mobility, and impact-absorbing to deaden the ball after a missed pitch.
Pads attached to the back of a catcher's shins to reduce fatigue and stress on a catcher's knees.
Gloves or mitts designed exclusively for the catcher position.
Guards or padding built to protect the catcher's knees, shins and ankles from things like wild pitches, cleats, blocking, and foul tips.
Collection of gear that usually consists of the foundational catchers gear like a helmet, chest protector and leg guards.
Protective headwear worn by baseball or softball catchers.
A high-drag projectile used in the sport of badminton.
Collection of items used to play badminton.
Sports equipment with a handle and strings used in the sport of badminton.

In camping, a ground pad, sleeping pad, thermal pad, sleeping mat, or roll mat is lightweight pad, common among hikers, backpackers and budget travelers, often used in conjunction with a sleeping bag. Its purpose is to provide padding and thermal insulation.
A wheeled, rolling insulated container generally used for the storage of food items.
A knife that is specially designed and weighted so that it can be thrown effectively in an overhand motion in a manner that causes the knife to rotate as it travels through the air.
A soft-sided insulated container generally used for the storage of food items.
A weapon usually thrown in an overhand motion in a manner that causes the axe to rotate as it travels through the air.
Items that are used for hammock hanging, mounting, or are compatible with a hammock in some way.
An air mattress, also known as an air bed or a blow-up bed, is an inflatable mattress made of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) or textile-reinforced urethane plastic or rubber.
Portable, lightweight, waterproof shelter, and an alternative to larger bivouac shelters.
A foldable knife with one or more blades that fit inside the handle that can still fit in a pocket. A typical blade length is 5 to 15 centimetres (2 to 6 in).
A classifier for items in “Backpacking & Camping Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
Portable stove designed for outdoor use while camping or picnicking.
Hydration system built as a backpack or waist pack containing a reservoir or "bladder" commonly made of rubber or flexible plastic.
A portable source of lighting, typically featuring a protective enclosure for the light source.
An additional storage device designed to attach onto an existing backpack.
Cots typically use a steel or aluminum frame and are equipped with a canvas or polyester pad for sleeping on.

Sleeping bag liners are lightweight cloth sacks usually fitted inside sleeping bags to provide extra comfort, insulation, and help keep the sleeping bag clean. A thin liner may feel softer against the sleeper's skin, add 5 °F warmth to the bag, and be easily washed after use.
A flashlight or torch is a portable hand-held electric lamp.
Objects that can accompany or accommodate a tent.
A tent footprint is a ground cloth made from waterproof material that lays between your tent bottom and the ground. Tent footprints are usually produced from sturdy but relatively lightweight fabric.
Whistle specifically designed to send out a blast for help that can be heard from long distances.
ice chest style, insulated beverage dispenser often intended for water or sports drinks.

A portable or mobile toilet is a term that covers several very different types of toilets, with the distinguishing feature that it may easily be moved around. A portable toilet can be brought to a location such as a music festival, camp site, or building site.
Portable devices to collect urine.
Bear Protection (such a bear pepper spray or air horns) are utilized as a deterrent for aggressive or charging bears.
Outerwear upper body garment with an opening for the head, intended to drape down over the body.
A pole supporting a tent.
Shelter constructed of screen material.
Button in or zip in pieces of fabric designed to make a sleeping bag larger.
Electronic device designed for the cooling and storage of food and drink.  Thermoelectric cooling relies on the Peltier effect instead of using a traditional compressor cooling system.
Covers, usually made from waterproof material, to create a barrier between the outer material of a pack and the weather.
Fuel utilized for a camping or backpacking stove.
Camping water filters are used by hikers and campers to filter water for safe consumption.

A meshed curtain that is circumferentially draped over a bed or a sleeping area, to offer the sleeper barrier protection against bites and stings from mosquitos, flies, and other pest insects, and thus against the diseases they may carry.
Kits utilized to fix a damaged tent.
A representation of an area, a diagram of the celestial sphere, or a visual representation of the relative position of something.

A sleeping bag is an insulated covering for a person, essentially a lightweight quilt that can be closed with a zipper or similar means to form a tube, which functions as lightweight, portable bedding in situations where a person is sleeping outdoors.

A tent peg is a spike, usually with a hook or hole on the top end, typically made from wood, metal, plastic, or composite material, pushed or driven into the ground for holding a tent to the ground, either directly by attaching to the tent's material, or by connecting to ropes attached to the tent.

A collection of common kitchen wares designed to be lightweight and easy to store. Kits usually come with either folding handles or a detachable handle which can be used with other cookware. Items are stored compactly by nesting them in other components.
Empty camping stove fuel bottles are containers meant to house camping replacement fuel, which is to provide fuel for a camping device.

A sack carried on one's back and secured with two straps that go over the shoulders, as well as often around the waist.  It can have an external frame or internal frame and is designed for carrying heavy loads or carrying any sort of equipment.

Low-weight, low-bulk blanket made of heat-reflective thin plastic sheeting. Their design reduces the heat loss in a person's body, which would otherwise occur due to thermal radiation, water evaporation, or convection.
A portable bowl-shaped fixture used for washing hands, dishwashing, and other purposes.
A storage device meant to make sleeping bags more portable.

Light sticks are task lights, cylindrical in form, with the illuminating face along the length (or part of the length) of the cylinder.  This is counter to a conventional flashlight where the illuminating face is generally found at an end.

A flask is a small container used to carry a small amount of liquid. A canteen is a drinking water bottle designed to be used by hikers, campers, soldiers and workers in the field. It is usually fitted with a shoulder strap or means for fastening it to a belt, and may be covered with a cloth bag and padding to protect the bottle and insulate the contents. A bota bag is a traditional Spanish liquid receptacle, used mainly as a wineskin. It is often made out of leather.

A hammock is a sling made of fabric, rope, or netting, suspended between two or more points, used for swinging, sleeping, or resting. It normally consists of one or more cloth panels, or a woven network of twine or thin rope stretched with ropes between two firm anchor points such as trees or posts.
A bag made of a thick insulating material that keeps food and drinks cold while traveling.

A beach tent is a shade structure consisting of sheets of fabric or other material draped over, attached to a frame of poles or attached to a supporting rope. While smaller tents may be free-standing or attached to the ground, large tents are usually anchored using guy ropes tied to stakes or tent pegs. Unlike traditional tents, beach tents often only have 2-3 walls, as to provide an opening.
A type of hydration system built containing a reservoir or "bladder" commonly made of rubber or flexible plastic.
A portable electric light which is meant to be worn on the head via a strap.
Folding or collapsible table designed for easy packing and use in a camping situation.
Belt designed to transfer the weight away from the shoulders when carrying a backpack.
Portable Shower Gear is anything meant to be utilize in bathing in lieu of a conventional shower. This can range, from portable shower tents, water bladders, and shower handles.
Chemical substances used to treat water for safe consumption.
A camping chair chair is a type of folding furniture; a light, portable chair.
A cooler (or jug) designed to store and dispense cool beverages.  This is *NOT* an ice chest style cooler.
A type of suspended seat, typically of woven material in the style of a hammock, usually made to accommodate one person in the seated position.
Walking poles are a common hiking accessory that function to assist walkers with their rhythm, to provide stability, and reduce strain on joints on rough terrain.
A pillow intended to work with a hammock.
A portable shelter made of cloth, that can be inflated or supported by one or more poles/ropes and stretched tight by cords or loops attached to pegs driven into the ground.
Backpack shoulder straps are attached to a back pack, utilized to carry the load of the pack.
An instrument used for navigation and orientation that shows direction relative to the geographic cardinal directions (or points).
Portable containers meant for the storage of potable water meant for consumption.
An insulated container designed for high performance storage of food items.
A hard-sided insulated container generally used for the storage of food items.
Portable devices used to purify water for safe consumption.
Hammock stands are wooden or metal stands that you can simply hook and unhook your hammock over.
Portable, compact stove designed for outdoor use while backpacking.
Blankets or mats used for picnics.
A knife with one or more military features designed for use in tactical situations.
A semi-rigid but elastic arc with a high-tensile bowstring joining the ends of the two limbs of the bow.
A general term for various types of weights, usually on rods, mounted on the bow to increase stability and lessen movement on release, thereby increasing precision.

An arrow is a fin-stabilized projectile launched by a bow. A typical arrow usually consists of a long, stiff, straight shaft with a weighty (and usually sharp and pointed) arrowhead attached to the front end, multiple fin-like stabilizers called fletchings mounted near the rear, and a slot at the rear end called nock for engaging the bowstring.
A dart-like projectile used by crossbows.
Objects in various forms and shapes that are used for shooting sports at which an attack is aimed.
A device that helps to fire arrows more precisely, by using a trigger to release the bowstring, rather than the archer's fingers.
A container or bag for carrying a bow.
The tip of the arrow that pierces the target.
A classifier for items in “Archery Supplies” that does not have a dedicated PT.
A small notch at the back end of the arrow to connect the arrow to the bowstring.

A large cutting point assembly, attached to an arrow shaft for hunting.
Device that reduces the required physical effort of cocking a bow.

Sling used to a attach the bow to the user.
A small leather or synthetic patch that protects an archer's fingers from the bowstring.
Any fin-like attachment used for stabilizing an arrow.

A rectangular board that a rider is attached to via boots and bindings, that is towed behind a boat.
Devices that hold a person's foot to the water sport board.
The rope a wakeboarder holds onto while being towed by a boat.
Watercraft of various shapes and sizes that are towed behind a boat.
Long, thing planks with upturned ends enabling the wearer to skim the surface of the water when towed by a motorboat.
A small board that a rider kneels on while being towed behind a boat.
Surfboard that is specially designed to be pulled behind a boat and used on the boat's wake.
Ropes and handles used by water-skiers as they are towed by the boat.
Boots worn by a wakeboarder that are inserted into the bindings.
A board similar to a wakeboard where the rider is not bound to the board.
A large board that a rider stands on, to which a sail is attached.
A wing-shaped fabric that attaches to the mast. It catches the wind and provides propulsion through the water.
A piece of equipment that attaches to the mast, providing structural support for the sail and enables directional control.
A pole that connects to the windsurfing board that keeps the sail upright.
Fins that attach or are permanently attached to the underside of a rideable water board that helps with stability and directional control while in the water.
Wax applied to boards.
Items used to assist in training for surfing.
A type of board used to skim on the surface of shallow water. It is smaller than a regular surfboard and does not have fins.
A short, light type of surfboard ridden in a prone position.
A long cord that attaches to a surfboard, connecting it to the leg or arm of a surfer. Used to stop runaway surfboards from hitting other surfers and swimmers.
A narrow plank used to ride waves.

Towels used in yoga.

Sandbags used in yoga to add weight for increased stretch during various poses.
Socks help to keep toes and feet in the right position firmly.

Cleaners are used to keep the yoga mat clean.

Props to use for stretching the inner thighs and hips etc.
